awd_titl_txt: Localized Finishing of Freeform Geometries using Dynamic Magnetic Field-Manipulated Magneto-Viscoelastic Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Demand for biomedical prosthetic implants (e.g., total hip joints) is growing by 5 percent annually and this market is expected to exceed $35B by 2019.  Local finishing of targeted regions of the surfaces of various joints is essential for their life assurance. The industry largely depends on laborious and expensive manual or chemical etching methods for localized finishing. This award supports fundamental research that can lead to new machine tools that use magnetic energy and abrasive-mixed magnetic "blob" (semisolid globule in a nonmagnetic fluid) for localized finishing of surfaces. These machine tools can be vital for affordable manufacturing of custom, functional free-form parts (e.g., durable, single piece prosthetic components).
 
The focus of this research is on the effects of the composition of the magnetic fluid as well as the spatio-temporal variation of the external magnetic fields on the selectivity and material removal rates over 1-10 sq. cm area on freeform parts made of diamagnetic or weak paramagnetic materials.  The first research objective is to establish quantitative relationships connecting the rheological properties of magnetic fluid blobs with their colloidal compositions and the spatio-temporal variation of external magnetic fields: This knowledge is essential to select magnetic field patterns that can create gradients conducive for optimal flow and selectivity of magnetic fluids, and make a blob exert appropriate down pressures. To achieve this objective, an experimental study will be conducted employing a specialized rheometer instrumented with array of magnets, Gauss meters, as well as force and vibration sensors. The rheometer provides a controlled means to estimate both the magneto-viscoelastic properties of the abrasive granular fluid (based on rubber elasticity theory) as well as the material removal rates for different fluid compositions and workpiece surfaces, and measure the induced magnetic field, forces, and the down pressure. The second objective is to establish a relationship between the localized magnetic field gradients induced over a magnetic blob and the applied spatio-temporal magnetic field:  The resulting knowledge will provide guidance to realize sharp magnetic gradients at specified locations, and design magnetic enclosures capable of creating these patterns. To achieve this objective, a novel implicit viscoelastic modeling approach will be employed. This approach uses the property relationships gathered from the first objective to provide a computationally efficient means to capture the blob behaviors, including smooth transition from a magneto-elastic solid like response to that of a magneto-viscoelastic fluid.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Recent advances in additive manufacturing has opened exciting possibilities to print components with intricate shapes. However, the texture of the surfaces created from additive manufacturing tend to be rough and not suitable for many real world applications. Localized finishing (or smoothening) of surfaces at targeted regions of the complex parts printed from additive manufacturing processes is essential to exploit the full potential of this advanced manufacturing technology. This project has  investigated a new approach based on varying an external magnetic field to manipulate magnetic fluid mixed with abrasives over the targeted portion of a complex component to create smooth surfaces with average roughness values (Ra) below 1 micrometer. As part of this project, a lab testbed was developed to evaluate the magnetic and flow properties of the magnetic fluids, as well as their effect smoothening the surfaces. Additionally, a prototype experimental setup for localized polishing was developed, and a proof of concept demonstration was successfully carried out. The prototype design of the localized polishing process is currently considered by the institution's intellectual property office for commercialization opportunities. Experimental studies conducted as part of this project have conclusively uncovered that the heat generated during the finishing process  is the chief cause of surface smoothening. This study supports various earlier analytical models to establish that much of the surface modifications during finishing processes is mediated through thermal softening, and not shear deformation. A consequence of this result is that the thermomechanical effects need to be considered for effective prediction of performance of the localized finishing processes.

This project has provided research opportunities and experiences to one post-doctoral associate, three graduate students, three REU scholars, and two other undergraduate students. Two of the REU scholars belong to the underrepresented minority groups. One of them received the best poster award at a regional student poster competition, as well as a prestigious Barany award from the Institute for Industrial and Systems Engineering. This is the highest award of excellence given to an undergraduate student pursuing a Baccalaureate degree in Industrial Engineering. Two of the undergraduate students are currently pursuing graduate studies.


Last Modified: 05/16/2019
Modified by: Satish T Bukkapatnam

    Demonstration of localized finishing
  • A test setup developed in this project to study the flow characteristics (specifically, rheology) of the magnetic fluids. a) Photograph of the test setup that mimics a torsional rheometer. b) A schematic of the setup showing a top plate and a bottom cup to hold the fluid.
    Naveen Thomas, Arun Srinivasa, Satish Bukkapatnam
    Copyrighted
    Satish T Bukkapatnam
    Experimental setup to study the flow characteristics of magnetic fluids
